It is important to conduct scientific research in Antarctica for a number of reasons, including:

1. Climate change research: The Antarctic ice sheet contains about 90% of the world's fresh water in the form of ice. Studying the changes in this ice sheet helps scientists understand how climate change is impacting our planet and how it might affect sea level rise.

2. Ocean circulation studies: Ocean currents around Antarctica play a critical role in regulating global climate by driving heat exchange between the atmosphere and ocean. Research on these currents can improve our understanding of weather patterns, both locally and globally.

3. Ecosystem studies: The uniquely harsh environment found at extreme latitudes such as Antarctica has resulted in equally unique ecosystems that provide valuable insight into life's ability to adapt and thrive under adverse conditions.

4. Geological study: As Antarctica was once part of Gondwana (an ancient supercontinent), studying its geology could help us better understand Earth's geological history, continental drift, and plate tectonics.

5. Meteorological observations: Extreme cold temperatures make Antarctic weather different from other parts of the world; understanding these differences improves our knowledge of global meteorological processes overall.

6. Cosmic ray observations: Because it lies beneath one magnetic pole with little human-induced radio interference or background cosmic rays from stars or airplanes flying overhead, researchers can collect extremely high-quality cosmic-ray data through telescope arrays set up near or even above South Pole Stationâ€”the largest neutrino detector ever built!
